blocks.name: nn0seqcvgd
blocks.content: A strictly-decreasing nonnegative integer sequence with initial term ` N ` reaches zero by the ` N ` th term. Deduction version. (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 31-Mar-2011.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: seq1st
blocks.content: A sequence whose iteration function ignores the second argument is only affected by the first point of the initial value function. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 11-Feb-2015.)
blocks.origin:

  -| wceq(c5, cfv(cuz, c0))
  -| wceq(c3, cseq(c0, ccom(c4, c1st), cxp(c5, csn(c1))))

  syl5eq(c3, cseq(c0, ccom(c4, c1st), csn(cop(c0, c1))), cseq(c0, ccom(c4, c1st), cxp(c5, csn(c1))), wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, c2)))

  seqfn(c0, ccom(c4, c1st), csn(cop(c0, c1)))

thm algr0(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wceq(cfv(c0, c1), c2))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cuz, c1))
  -| wceq(c0, cseq(c1, ccom(c4, c1st), cxp(c3, csn(c2))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, cz))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c2, c5))
} = {
  syl5eq(cfv(c0, c1), c2, cfv(cseq(c1, ccom(c4, c1st), cxp(c3, csn(c2))), c1), w0)
  fveq1i(c0, c1, cseq(c1, ccom(c4, c1st), cxp(c3, csn(c2))))
  eqtrd(cfv(cseq(c1, ccom(c4, c1st), cxp(c3, csn(c2))), c1), c2, cfv(cxp(c3, csn(c2)), c1), w0)
  syl(w0, wceq(cfv(cseq(c1, ccom(c4, c1st), cxp(c3, csn(c2))), c1), cfv(cxp(c3, csn(c2)), c1)), wcel(c1, cz))
  seq1(c1, ccom(c4, c1st), cxp(c3, csn(c2)))
  syl2anc(w0, wceq(cfv(cxp(c3, csn(c2)), c1), c2), wcel(c2, c5), wcel(c1, c3))
  syl6eleqr(c1, c3, cfv(cuz, c1), w0)
  syl(w0, wcel(c1, cfv(cuz, c1)), wcel(c1, cz))
  uzid(c1)
  fvconst2g(c2, c5, c1, c3)
}

thm algr0(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, wff w0) {
  ⊢ (w0 →(c0 ` c1)= c2)
  ⊣ c3 =(ℤ≥ ` c1)
  ⊣ c0 = seq(c1((c4 ∘ 1st),(c3 × { c2 })))
  ⊣ (w0 → c1 ∈ ℤ)
  ⊣ (w0 → c2 ∈ c5)
} = {
  syl5eq((c0 ` c1), c2, (seq(c1((c4 ∘ 1st),(c3 × { c2 })))` c1), w0)
  fveq1i(c0, c1, seq(c1((c4 ∘ 1st),(c3 × { c2 }))))
  eqtrd((seq(c1((c4 ∘ 1st),(c3 × { c2 })))` c1), c2, ((c3 × { c2 })` c1), w0)
  syl(w0, (seq(c1((c4 ∘ 1st),(c3 × { c2 })))` c1)=((c3 × { c2 })` c1), c1 ∈ ℤ)
  seq1(c1, (c4 ∘ 1st), (c3 × { c2 }))
  syl2anc(w0, ((c3 × { c2 })` c1)= c2, c2 ∈ c5, c1 ∈ c3)
  syl6eleqr(c1, c3, (ℤ≥ ` c1), w0)
  syl(w0, c1 ∈(ℤ≥ ` c1), c1 ∈ ℤ)
  uzid(c1)
  fvconst2g(c2, c5, c1, c3)
}

blocks.name: algrf
blocks.content: An algorithm is a step function ` F : S --> S ` on a state space ` S ` . An algorithm acts on an initial state ` A e. S ` by iteratively applying ` F ` to give ` A ` , ` ( F `` A ) ` , ` ( F `` ( F `` A ) ) ` and so on. An algorithm is said to halt if a fixed point of ` F ` is reached after a finite number of iterations. The algorithm iterator ` R : NN0 --> S ` "runs" the algorithm ` F ` so that ` ( R `` k ) ` is the state after ` k ` iterations of ` F ` on the initial state ` A ` . Domain and codomain of the algorithm iterator ` R ` . (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 31-Mar-2011.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 28-May-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm algrf(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wf(c0, c1, c2))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cuz, c3))
  -| wceq(c0, cseq(c3, ccom(c4, c1st), cxp(c1, csn(c5))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c3, cz))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c5, c2))
  -| wi(w0, wf(c4, c2, c2))
} = {
  sylibr(w0, wf(c0, c1, c2), wf(cseq(c3, ccom(c4, c1st), cxp(c1, csn(c5))), c1, c2))
  seqf(hs0, hs1, c3, ccom(c4, c1st), cxp(c1, csn(c5)), c1, c2, w0)
  eqeltrd(cfv(cxp(c1, csn(c5)), cv(hs0)), c2, c5, wa(w0, wcel(cv(hs0), c1)))
  sylan(w0, wcel(cv(hs0), c1), wceq(cfv(cxp(c1, csn(c5)), cv(hs0)), c5), wcel(c5, c2))
  fvconst2g(c5, c2, cv(hs0), c1)
  adantr(w0, wcel(cv(hs0), c1), wcel(c5, c2))
  syl5eqel(co(cv(hs0), ccom(c4, c1st), cv(hs1)), c2, cfv(c4, cv(hs0)), wa(w0, wa(wcel(cv(hs0), c2), wcel(cv(hs1), c2))))
  algrflem(cv(hs0), c4, cv(hs1))
  vex(hs0)
  vex(hs1)
  syl2an(w0, wa(wcel(cv(hs0), c2), wcel(cv(hs1), c2)), wcel(cfv(c4, cv(hs0)), c2), wf(c4, c2, c2), wcel(cv(hs0), c2))
  simpl(wcel(cv(hs0), c2), wcel(cv(hs1), c2))
  ffvelrn(c4, c2, c2, cv(hs0))
  feq1i(c0, c1, c2, cseq(c3, ccom(c4, c1st), cxp(c1, csn(c5))))
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.c(c3)
  diff.hs0.c(ccom(c4, c1st))
  diff.hs0.c(cxp(c1, csn(c5)))
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
  diff.hs0.c(c2)
  diff.hs1.c(c3)
  diff.hs1.c(ccom(c4, c1st))
  diff.hs1.c(cxp(c1, csn(c5)))
  diff.hs1.c(c2)
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
  diff.hs1.w(w0)
}

thm algrf(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, wff w0) {
  ⊢ (w0 →(c0 : c1 → c2))
  ⊣ c1 =(ℤ≥ ` c3)
  ⊣ c0 = seq(c3((c4 ∘ 1st),(c1 × { c5 })))
  ⊣ (w0 → c3 ∈ ℤ)
  ⊣ (w0 → c5 ∈ c2)
  ⊣ (w0 →(c4 : c2 → c2))
} = {
  sylibr(w0, (c0 : c1 → c2), (seq(c3((c4 ∘ 1st),(c1 × { c5 }))): c1 → c2))
  seqf(hs0, hs1, c3, (c4 ∘ 1st), (c1 × { c5 }), c1, c2, w0)
  eqeltrd(((c1 × { c5 })` hs0), c2, c5, (w0 ∧ hs0 ∈ c1))
  sylan(w0, hs0 ∈ c1, ((c1 × { c5 })` hs0)= c5, c5 ∈ c2)
  fvconst2g(c5, c2, hs0, c1)
  adantr(w0, hs0 ∈ c1, c5 ∈ c2)
  syl5eqel((hs0[(c4 ∘ 1st)]hs1), c2, (c4 ` hs0), (w0 ∧(hs0 ∈ c2 ∧ hs1 ∈ c2)))
  algrflem(hs0, c4, hs1)
  vex(hs0)
  vex(hs1)
  syl2an(w0, (hs0 ∈ c2 ∧ hs1 ∈ c2), (c4 ` hs0)∈ c2, (c4 : c2 → c2), hs0 ∈ c2)
  simpl(hs0 ∈ c2, hs1 ∈ c2)
  ffvelrn(c4, c2, c2, hs0)
  feq1i(c0, c1, c2, seq(c3((c4 ∘ 1st),(c1 × { c5 }))))
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.c(c3)
  diff.hs0.c((c4 ∘ 1st))
  diff.hs0.c((c1 × { c5 }))
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
  diff.hs0.c(c2)
  diff.hs1.c(c3)
  diff.hs1.c((c4 ∘ 1st))
  diff.hs1.c((c1 × { c5 }))
  diff.hs1.c(c2)
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
  diff.hs1.w(w0)
}

  syl(wa(w0, wcel(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(cseq(c4, ccom(c3, c1st), cxp(c1, csn(c5))), co(c0, caddc, nat1)), co(cfv(cseq(c4, ccom(c3, c1st), cxp(c1, csn(c5))), c0), ccom(c3, c1st), cfv(cxp(c1, csn(c5)), co(c0, caddc, nat1)))), wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, c4)))

blocks.name: algcvg
blocks.content: One way to prove that an algorithm halts is to construct a countdown function ` C : S --> NN0 ` whose value is guaranteed to decrease for each iteration of ` F ` until it reaches ` 0 ` . That is, if ` X e. S ` is not a fixed point of ` F ` , then ` ( C `` ( F `` X ) ) < ( C `` X ) ` . If ` C ` is a countdown function for algorithm ` F ` , the sequence ` ( C `` ( R `` k ) ) ` reaches ` 0 ` after at most ` N ` steps, where ` N ` is the value of ` C ` for the initial state ` A ` . (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 22-Jun-2011.)

blocks.name: algcvgb
blocks.content: Two ways of expressing that ` C ` is a countdown function for algorithm ` F ` . The first is used in these theorems. The second states the condition more intuitively as a conjunction: if the countdown function's value is currently nonzero, it must decrease at the next step; if it has reached zero, it must remain zero at the next step. (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 31-Mar-2011.)

blocks.name: algcvga
blocks.content: The countdown function ` C ` remains ` 0 ` after ` N ` steps. (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 22-Jun-2011.)

blocks.name: algfx
blocks.content: If ` F ` reaches a fixed point when the countdown function ` C ` reaches ` 0 ` , ` F ` remains fixed after ` N ` steps. (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 22-Jun-2011.)
